summary: After leaving their prom early, innocent Jenny (Renée Zellweger) and three other teenagers crash their car in the backwoods of Texas. In their search for help, they run into Vilmer Slaughter (Matthew McConaughey), a vicious psychopath with a mechanical leg, and his twisted family, including the serial killer Leatherface. As the group of friends struggle to survive the maniacal methods of torture, Jenny discovers the secret origins behind the family's lust for blood.

Despite talent like Renee Zellweger and Matthew McConaughey appearing in this film, Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Next Generation (1994) is disastrous. Right from the start the characters established are the worst, whether that is extremely irritating, obnoxious or just plain boring, you hope that they get killed to put yourself out of your misery. Other than that, as a Texas Chainsaw Massacre movie it feels distant, with certain details ignoring what had come previous and in some cases just straight up changing them, for example changing the Sawyer's family name to the Slaughter's. And of the Slaughter family, they all act far too ridiculous to find scary, even more so than what the family originally acted like. The main culprit of this is Matthew McConaughey's character Vilmer who is constantly shouting and acting weird where it is just stupid instead of actually showing how crazy he is.
Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Next Generation (1994) marks a low point for a franchise which never needed to be more than one film long.
Matthew McConaughey was so good in this movie. I can't believe it was one of his first roles cause he was amazing.

Written and directed by Kim Henkel, who wrote the original film, this take on the Sawyer family has sadly been forgotten, but it had — as so many films do — a rocky creation, a two year period where it disappeared and features two big stars who pretty much don't want anything to do with it. It's also the last movie in the original timeline of the films before remake and reboot and reimagining became the constant status quo for chainsaw movies.

I can see why some people dislike this movie. After all, there's now a thousand-year-old secret society paying off the Sawyers — who now choose pizza over human flesh — to kill people to keep the population in a constant state of fear. Or maybe they do it so people can achieve transcendence through that terror. Leatherface, who used to be a killing machine, now struggles with not only his ability to capture and murder the teengers, but his sexuality, cross-dressing and screaming like a child.

He also does not use a chainsaw.

The real center of this story is Renée Zellweger's Jenny, who Henkel wrote the story around, claiming that was about "her transformation, her refusal to shut up, to be silenced, to be victimized. And by extension her refusal to be oppressed." In the director's cut, it's shown that she's been abused her whole life, so the terror of the Sawyers leaves her unafraid.

Actually, they're now the Slaughters, not the Sawyers, and led by the other big star in this production — he wasn't at the time — Matthew McConaughey as Vilmer Slaughter, a maniac who combines the characteristics of the HItchhiker, Chop Top and Leatherface with a cybernetic leg and the need to self-scar himself. His wife Darla reveals much of the conspiracy theory in the film, except that she also claims that she has a bomb implanted in her skull and that Vilmer is from space.

This movie played 27 theaters, then Japan and then disappeared for two years, as CAA wanted nothing to ruin the success of McConaughey. It finally played in twenty cities in 1997. Yet it has its fans, as no less a Chainsaw fan as Joe Bob Briggs said, "This is the best horror film of the 90s" and called this "a flick so terrifying and brilliant that it makes the other two Chainsaw sequels sceem like "After-School Specials."

The end of the film features John Dugan, Grandfather from The Texas Chainsaw Massacre, Paul A. Partain, who was Franklin and Marilyn Burns, who was Sally. I love that she locks eyes with Kenny as the movie closes. I also adore that this movie has so many Texas bands, like "Der Einziger Weg" by Debbie Harry and Robert Jacks (who was Leather in this), plus songs by Roky Erickson and Daniel Johnston.

With inconsistent tones and tension, mostly bad acting, and almost no good scares, The Next Generation manages to earn the title of the worst Texas Chainsaw movie. Matthew McConaughey is perfectly over-the-top crazy as Vilmer, and Tonie Perenski is surprisingly funny as Vilmer's girlfriend Darla, but the rest of the cast are pretty bad. There are a handful of genuinely scary moments, but they're few and far between. On top of all that, the film makes the mistake of going down the same road as Halloween 6, and in this case tries to connect Leatherface's family to the Illuminati, which is just completely stupid.

A bizarre entry that criticizes bad horror sequels by being the worst kind imaginable before actually having a suited boss character show up to point out the ineptitude of the movies villains. It seems Kim Henkel, co-writer of the original movie and director of this one, wanted to make a movie about how Hollywood hires untalented filmmakers to try to recapture the magic of a superior predecessor with disastrous results. Sure it's awful, but its awful for a reason.

They try to throw in some other little plot about some spiritual experience with some guy in a suit but it comes out of nowhere and makes no sense at all.  They made Leatherface into a transvestite which isn't even funny or scary on paper, and worse is practice. The characters have little to no personality. The acting is awful, incredibly annoying is more accurate. Zellweger seems asleep half the time and McConaughey hams it up, which even that didn't save it. Don't even bother with this one horror fans, its not even remotely worth it. It fails to be original, it fails to be scary, it fails to be funny, it just fails.

This Pathetic film had a very rough, complicated and strange history. Made in 1994 starring "unknown" actors (at the time) Renee Zewelleger and Matthew McConaughey on a $600,000 budget. Shown at a few film festivals, titled as "The Return of The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" before being shoveled due to occasions between the producers and people at Colombia Pictures in the process, being in post-production too long, and re-edited so much, up until it was stupidity given a limited theatrical re-release in 1997 re-titled as The Next Generation. And what else they did to it was cut the timing to about 86 minutes in this movie, while about 95 minutes it originally was (before re-editing and re-releasing; which are mainly scenes when Jenny is abused by her father before prom, they cut out those scenes in TNG).

I would consider myself a Texas Chainsaw Massacre fan since the very first. So when my best friend brought to my attention that this movie existed I was in shock.  When we flipped on this movie...we were in complete shell shock. So the plot itself makes absolutely no sense. In fact there really isn't a plot. Some kids get together after a dance and we are introduced to a cast that is cliche as all hell and that we've seen a thousand times before. The slut, the joker or normal guy, the jock or asshole in this case, and of course...the virgin whose innocent and somehow survives at the end. Well things just drag on for a bit in the beginning than we are introduced to Matthew McConaughey's character who is completely insane with a robot leg, that is never explained at all.It is very bizarre and surreal to see this all unfold. One by one the kids are picked off, and the character portraying the "asshole" is extremely stupid, and the acting in this movie is horrendous except for McConaughey's character. He is the best part of the movie and what is keeping me from rating this significantly lower. He is completely over the top and performing at his ten. He is off the wall, maniacal and insane. The worst part of this movie is seeing Leatherface dressed up in drag, its a complete mockery to the franchise. The absolute worst part of this movie is the involvement of the Illuminati in a strange attempt to make this movie have some time of sense. They also tried extremely hard to replicate scenes from the original in what comes off as stale and lame. The ending however is the biggest insult to the franchise is the tie in with Sally from the original. Stay clear of this movie if you are a fan of the Texas Chainsaw Massacre, but if you are a cult fim fan. check it out will definitely keep you laughing and entertained. For what its worth anyways.

In 1994, a little piece of horror died. While it wouldn't be released in theaters for another three years due to the mindful hesitation from the film's distributor, TEXAS CHAINSAW MASSACRE: THE NEXT GENERATION was born. Touted to be a remake of the original by TEXAS CHAIN SAW MASSACRE co-writer Kim Henkel, THE NEXT GENERATION follows all of the same action beats, but misses the point entirely. It isn't that people just don't 'get' TEXAS CHAINSAW 4, which is typically the case with the second film. It just really is as bad as everyone says. The so-called dark humor is completely lost on the audience. If there is anything worse than the unintelligible script, it is the atrocious acting. No one in the entire cast gives a shit about what they are doing. It often feels as if they were drugged and forced to act against their will, although the teens' ambivalence towards the horror that is unfolding around them earns the only guilty laugh. The hope would be that Henkel would make up for his artless production by splattering the screen with some gratuitous gore, but THE NEXT GENERATION is even more bloodless than the third film. TEXAS CHAINSAW MASSACRE 4 is universally considered to be the worst in the series, and rightfully so.

-Carl Manes

It surprises me how much hate their is for this movie.  It's not "good", but I don't get how there is so much hate for what is honestly the closest thing to the original Texas Chainsaw Massacre.  That's not just in the plot (which is basically identical to the original), but it's a really gritty film that is full of characters that are very similar to the original.  This film actually depicts Leatherface more closely to how he was portrayed in the first movie, yet for some reason it's a huge part of people's hatred of this film.  McConaughey gives a pretty decent performance and there is plenty of action and interesting turns to keep the viewer interested through the entire running time.

That said, the movie isn't really "good".  A lot of the major reveals make no sense and almost feel tacked on to make the movie seem more important than it is.  Renee Zellweger is particularly bad.  The scene with her and McConaughey in the truck almost feels completely ad-libbed and Zellweger seems like she doesn't even know what to say.  Many of her scenes are hard to watch (and she's pretty much in the entire movie).  She must be thrilled that this movie didn't have a wide release until after Jerry Maguire because this is one performance no actress should ever put on her reel.  I'm not trying to hate on her because I actually do think she's grown into a fine actress, but just not in this movie.

Overall, this movie is not as bad as everyone makes it out to be.  It's not even the worst Texas Chainsaw movie.  2006's The Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Beginning is one of the worst movies I've seen, and while Texas Chainsaw Massacre 3 may have had better production value I found this movie to be more entertaining overall.

A mess. A noisy awful mess.

An early film from the a-list careers of Zellweger and McConaughey that shows one would become a star while the other still had a lot of polishing to do. McConaughey gives a good performance (at least with what the script offered him) whil Zellweger showed moments of what was to come and moments of utter face slapping badness. Texas Chainsaw Massacre The Next Generation is a terrible compared to the original and other installments as its only saving grace is McConaughey and family. Leatherface and family all do a fine job with the ridiculous script written by Kim Henkel. Henkel's script isn't terrible but her use of dialogue is so bad that it may be the scariest thing about the movie ("Please stop killing me"). A sad addition to what had been the best horror franchise to this point.
LOL this movie makes me giggle.  It's just fun.
Not bad, but not great. McConaughey is pretty freaky in this film. Worth a watch.

This one SUCKED. Not funny. Corny in the worst way possible. Silly and just flat out dumb. Kim Henkel (who helped Hooper write the original TCM) directed this piece of sh*t. Thank God this is the only movie he directed. I wouldn't be able to bare anymore embarrassment watching his films. The Next Generation is more than a movie about torture...it's a movie that tortures the audience (in the worst of ways). I don't mean by it's display of extreme violence, because trust me, this movie isn't violent at all. It tortures us by it's unfunny childish ways. A twelve year old could make a movie like this. It doesn't take brains to be an idiot. Henkel...you're an idiot. 

I just thank God that Hooper was the director of the original Chainsaw, and not Henkel. Otherwise there would never exist such a classic that redefined the genre. The Next Generation blows.

This one is a stinker. More of a parody remake than a true sequel, the film fails to me funny or scary. It's plot is confusing and the characters are awful. Leatherface is more annoying than menacing. The movie is just a mess.

Early in their careers Renee Zellweger and Matthew McConaughey star in this, the fourth TCM. Four high school students get stranded after getting in an accident on their way home from their senior prom. After walking through the woods for help, they happen upon a small town and find a trashy real estate agent working late in her office.  She calls for a tow truck for them, but the tow truck driver is a murderous half-cyborg. Soon the kids locate a house in the woods in which resides a whole family of murderers including Leatherface (who is now a tranny, btw!). And somehow aliens and a secret society of assassins are involved. Of course they torture and kill the kids. Its actually rather comedic, which I propose was missed by most viewers. Yes, some bad dialog, wooden acting, and a tired script, but not nearly as bad as most other reviewers would have you believe.
seems more like a parody of elements from the original and those of the worst 80's slasher films.

What is to be said of Texas Chainsaw: The Next Generation, which tries to reimagine the family with new blood and features some of the earliest performances by both Renee Zellweger and Matthew McConaughey??? Mostly tired and boring, TCM: Next Generation suffers the fate of most TCm sequels--it never manages to reach the levels of gritty, visceral horror that the original remains so well renowned for.  Entertaining but ultimately crap, TCM: Next Generation should only be of interest to fans who want to see the whole series or those who enjoy watching completely crappy horror films.
A terribly made film that is almost too bad to laugh at. But it scores some points for being disgusting. 3.5/10

God awful sequel has no business existing at all, it all killed the franchise until the 2003 remake. With insulting stereotypes, and a cobbled story, even though it was co-written by the original screenwriter Kim Henkel, and bad plot line to guide(or misguide)viewers that it might get better as it goes along. Four teens on there way to their high school prom get derailed by one member of the cannibalistic clan(a chewing up the scenery Matthew McConaughey.)The ending will confuse the hell out of you. Leartherface is made up to look like Roseanne Barr with a chainsaw. A seriously dismal sequel, for die hard fans of McConaughey and Renee Zellweger, otherwise avoid this one at all cost!
One of my favs just by how WTF it is

This got 3 1/2 stars not because it is effective as a horror movie or as a sequel.  It got mosts of its star power from the fact that it is fall out of your chair hilarious.  The performances are all really camp and everyone in this film made me laugh at least three times.  This movie is really Hollywood and has a large stink from the dead teenager movies that were popular at the time (Scream, etc.).  The horror elements form the first movie are largely forgotten in the grand scheme and this film really was made (I think) to satirize the original.  It is the opposite end of the spectrum from the original.  While the original was made to be scary and almost documentary style, this film was made to be funny (or someone really underestimated what the horror audience would eat up as horror).  The performance of Lisa Newmeyer as Heather is either the stupidest performance ever or was made to be outrageously funny.  Anyway, this film is so amazingly bad that it is hilarious, especially considering that two very talented actors were in it.  It is, overall, very entertaining and anyone who watches it that can take it for what it is (a comedy) will definitely enjoy it.

This disaster of a movie I will defend only to say that it is not as atrocious as everyone makes it out to be. It is a black comedy missing the 'comedy' part. The acting is, especially from Zellweger and McConaughey, more painful to endure than being in a room with Peter Popoff for 80-minutes - overacting so dreadful I have to wonder if the actors deliberately tried to sabotage the movie. 'TCM: The Next Generation' is craziness for the sake of being crazy and fails to be entertaining or even interesting in a WTF-am-I-watching way. Ironically no one dies by Leatherface's chainsaw making the title only accurate about Texas. Adding to the inanity is the fact the movie is an ugly looking and moronic remake of the original effectively raping a horror classic. Leatherface is a cross dresser and I am still not sure why but it certainly turned him into a parody of an iconic villain. So, yeah, 'Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Next Generation' fails every second and only gets worse. Avoid it like a Pauly Shore movie.
with a title called the next generation you cant resist to make a star trek joke. :) but this movie is not great just okay

There are few words to describe the exquisite badness that is this movie.  Lame and under/over-acted by everyone, it's certainly crap.  But it's entertaining crap, and in the end that's all that matters.

This film does not even deservea half a star! This is such a terrible movie.
Here they made one of the first slasher killers ever into a crying,moaning,baby...that won't shut the heck up.
one of the worst movies i have ever seen.  trailor trash eat your heart out.

Tired and worn out... this film itself just tells you why there is no more sequels to the original series! Not interesting, bad acting and quite frankly leather-face has grown to be very unoriginal! The series truly needed the reboot to make Leatherface relevant again! It amazes me how the writers and directors produce pointless sequels, when they could have been so much better.
I pretty much doubt Renee Zellweger and Matthew McConoughy got their big break from this!........And if they did, then my faith in Hollywood is gone!
Boring...and very very gore free...yeah a chainsaw massacre movie with no gore what-so-ever. Unless you wanna see Renee Zellweger and Matthew McConaughey in their less famous days...

Texas Chainsaw Massacre Next Generation 

Renee Zellweger No, don't go out there! He's going to kill! (Crying and terrified) 
Darla Oh there's nothing there (steps outside) hey, come out if you got any balls? Hello, fun's over (looks each direction) Hey, are you there? (Turns around and goes back inside) there was nothing out there! 
Renee Zellweger Wait, what (she questions)? There was a guy chasing me with a chainsaw (calm) 
Me (laugh) that is one of the funniest scenes from an incompetently written and directed film by Kim Henkel in Texas Chainsaw Massacre: Next Generation. Hi, I'm Sleez Boy and today it's the sliced and dice 'em Return of the Texas Chainsaw Massacre. 

It's been 20 years since the first one came out in 1974 written by Kim Henkel and Tobey Hooper (director). Since then, none of the sequels came close to becoming an instant cult classic or a terrifying. Texas Chainsaw Massacre the Next Generation is the fourth film and it will shock and puzzle folks. Not that it's suspenseful, gory, or scary, but it's incompetent. I was watching the film thinking about what Henkel wanted with this film. It opens up with teenagers at the prom and it takes no time in identifying the soon to be victims. The script then takes them to the standard travel-slasher formula. 

Travel-slasher happens when a group of friends get lost in the middle of nowhere based on a number of factors like wrong direction or their tire is blown out. 

Example: Wrong Turn, House of a 1000 Corpses, Wolf Creek, the Hills Have Eyes and others 

The film then moves on to a remake because the scenes are very similar to the original one until it becomes its own film somewhere around the plot. I was wondering about Henkel's intentions with the film. I believe he was making a standard slasher film until he decides to remake the film as the shooting went on, but found out that the film was doom, so he went on to make something kooky. Whatever it was, he wasn't trying in the film as the acting and dialogue was flimsy. There are bad human interactions that will lead to huge laughs and scenes that will annoy. 

The journey begins when Heather (Lisa Marie Newmyer) and Barry (Tyler Shea Cone) get in a fight over inane reasons and argue with each other with ludicrous arguments. The two are spooked when they find out that Sean (John Harrison) and Jenny (Renee Zellweger) are behind the backseat and argue some more. They all talk to each other until they hit a car with man whose name is unknown. Heather, Jenny, and Barry go for a walk to find some help as their car is destroyed. They go to a place and ask for help where they are greeted by a peculiar possibly nymphomaniac Darla (Tonie Perensky).  She calls Vilmer (Matthew McConaughey) to locate Sean and unknown man to pick them up. He does and the conversation goes like this 

Vilmer Hey, this boy is dead. 
Sean What, he's alive. He's breathing and talking in his sleep! 
Vilmer Oh really? (Snaps stranger's neck) 
Sean Ah, why are you scaring me? 
Vilmer (runs over Sean) 

Little do the three know, they walk down the road and try to get a ride from a passing truck driver and go after the driver leaving the nerdy Jenny behind? Jenny is left all alone and goes on to wander the road by herself. She goes on until she is picked up by a strange man in truck titled The Wrecking whose driver is no other than Vilmer. Who would have guessed it? He begins to spook and creeps her out until she discovers how evil he is. Meanwhile, Sean and Heather walk around a road that is the same as the original's plotline as they go look around a house that's two stories tall. From there, they begin to uncover the horrors inside the house and are attacked by Leatherface. (Motor sound) 

We go back to Jenny. Hey Jenny, how are you doing? Well, she's running like the standard slasher formula and the madman Vilmer is chasing her down with his truck. Unlike her boyfriend Sean, she moves into the woods to avoid being road kill. Vilmer taunts her before leaving her in the dark for good, so what is a girl to do now? Kiss time bubble time, perhaps, room-room, she breathes and catches her air, twig snap. She stays there in the dark looking around room-rum until the motor noise starts off with a man popping out of nowhere. Yikes Scooby, we got to move! It is here that the usual pursuing scene begins with male attacker and the final girl, boring huh. She screams and runs even though she could have easily out run Leatherface since he is a big round guy carrying a large chainsaw. She finds a house to hide, but doesn't know that's where Leatherface lives. She becomes a fighter and becomes masculine as she toughens up and commits act of daring action glass shatters. Soon enough, she manages to escape for now. Watching this part of the film, I began laughing a lot more constantly because it was pretty silly and couldn't take the film serious. Now, I'm going back lights off. 

Jenny manages to escape and runs into Darla which is where I began my review. Anyways, not to anyone's surprise, Darla is associated with loons and has Jenny captured and tied up. She meets is taken back to the house for a nice dinner party where we meet the entire psycho family. One of them is a hillbilly that quotes a lot of famous guys in the scenes. The other is the grandfather that doesn't move or say a lot. Finally, we get two unknown folks that are in the same status as grandfather. However, the fun doesn't begin until Vilmer arrive along with some with cross dressing chainsaw wielding Leatherface. This scene and part becomes a torture scene where there is a lot of shouting, screaming, and hitting that become bizarrely funny. I didn't know how to handle the droll. There is then scene of more torture and shouting matches that become pretty funny and disturbing that'll make you wince. It is here that I gave up on reasoning with the logic and went along as Henkel stopped trying. In the end, I felt like waiving a chainsaw and writing a sloppy review due to the film's incompetence. 

I thought there was no point to analyze the film because what is the point of taking this flick seriously. It's obviously been sliced into obscurity due to the ridiculous writing and directing. It's most puzzling revolves around the motive behind the silliness that makes this film into a cartoon. If there was a movie to compare it to, I would compare this film to the hilarious, but incompetent Pootie Tang. It's extremely lousy and awful, but yet it's entertaining as ever. As the motive to Texas Chainsaw Massacre Next Generation remains unanswered, the film's acting is moderately okay. The scenes with the teenagers were odd as emotions and interaction was bizarre like Jenifer's Body status. There's one scene where Leatherface stands behind and starts rubbing on her hair and she doesn't pay attention or say get your filthy hands off of me! I couldn't get into it nor identify with the character, and then there's Matthew McConaughey (feminist worst enemy). His performance as an unstable and demented psychopath that screams and shouts throughout the film works. It's so easy to manipulate the demented psychopath, but yet it worked.  Zellweger's performance was not too shabby as she does a fine job as the nerdy girl who becomes endanger and screams until she becomes masculine to survive. Her performances are convincing despite the lousy writing, but her screaming and McConaughey's laughter made the experience a little too uncomfortable. I write this because it's very exploitive when you have scenes of girls screaming while the masculine b*****d chases her with a weapon. It's so easy to shoot a scene like that, but it's hard to make it scary once you seen this happen a number of times. Robert Jacks was pretty good as Leatherface because he doesn't have to do anything other chase a person around although he over stepped his boundaries and portrayed the killer as a disturbed person with voices in his head. The music is pretty good as we get a lot of southern heavy metal bands. As for the direction, it's blind or that of a drunken foolish man. 

Texas Chainsaw Massacre: the Next Generation is a film not to be taken serious room-room. It's pretty funny and droll. There are convincing performances despite the inane writing, rum-room, and the unintentionally funny human reaction. There must have been a serious idea or vision Henkel wanted, but got lazy halfway or most likely at the beginning of the writing and resulting in this trash that teaches to solve our life's problems with a chainsaw. This Sleazy signing off and I'll be watching some flicks rum-room chainsaw sound!
Honestly i only saw the end but this will definetely be shitty
This movie is erratic on a galactic scale.  It doesn't make any sense and is an annoying collection of failures.  it's not even funny.  And as is that wasn't enough, it starts off as a teen movie.

wow i have to say im very suprised by this, i was suprised i wasn't bored by this. it was so strange and so horrible at the same time. the actors were horrible, the only shining star is Matthew McConaughey and i say that because he really became his character. It was creepy seeing him in this bizarre light. Renee Zellwegger was annoying to be honest. The most annoying people is the guy that played W.E. and this version of Leatherface; i swear to god this interpretation of Leatherface was fuckin horrible. Leatherface wasn't terrifying in the least he was just hilarious in a bad way. I mean what was supposed to be the most terrifying character in this film turned out being the most hilarious one. Then when Leatherface fully dressed like an old woman was fuckin horrible. This and The Texas Chainsaw Massacre 2 are so far the worst in the "Texas Chainsaw" films.
great Cast for this one !

It was about 45 minutes in that I realized this was supposed to be a parody of the first "Texas Chainsaw Massacre" and when viewed as such, it's not entirely terrible. There's a few chuckles to be had from the sheer wackiness that is the latter part of this movie. I lol'd heartily when Renee Zellweger told Leatherface to "sit the f*ck down"--and he complied. 

But then it all could just as easily be that halfway through shooting the filmmakers realized they had a P.O.S. on their hands and thus decided to ramp up the humor so if anyone called them out on the cringe worthy footage they could play the "it was intentional" card.

So let us just assume that it was supposed to be a spoof from the get-go: the movie is still a HUGE mess. How did the self-proclaimed bitch get off the meat hook and crawl a mile down the road with nobody noticing? And why does nobody's dialogue have anything to do with the lines that immediately precede them? Is there an uncut version that I'm just missing or something?
this movie was terrible the acting was horrible it is the same as the first one, but the difference is the cast
This is a funny version of TCM.

Probably one of the worst sequels to the original Texas Chainsaw Massacre. Here the film itself is much worse than the previous Texas Chainsaw Massacre sequels (2 and 3) because here in the next generation Leatherface isn't even scary anymore and Leatherface started wearing a girl's outfit and the acting was terrible for one reason Leatherface was gay in this sequel for one reason. When I saw this at Cinemax I was like "What the Hell? Why did I even watch this?" I just can't believe that this one sucked alot and it wasn't as good as the original Texas Chainsaw Massacre because the film itself isn't scary anymore the movie itself is gay for one reason. Director Km Henkel (the guy who helped Tobe Hooper with the first film) wasn't good in directing and I'm glad that there will be no more sequels after this one. I'll just remember that the original, the remake and the prequel to the remake will always be the best in the Texas Chainsaw Massacre Franchise.
Why anyone related to this abomination still has a career is beyond me.

A couple words came to mind after I finished this. Awful. Horrible. Just to name a few. By far one of the worst movies I've ever seen, the plot is so repetitive to the first three "Chainsaw" movies that a twelve year could of wrote this if he saw them all. Terrible movie.

I decided to watch the series of TCM films that had been made and boy, this was a boring and funny trip.

First of all, they made Leatherface so affeminite, he is seriously wearing a smooth white mask with make up, a wig and women's clothing on.  I guess they were trying to touch on something psychological with that but they failed horribly and turned a horror movie icon into a dumbass who wears women's clothing.  His scream at the end of the film was extraordinarily funny too.

There is also this thing that confused me a lot, cuz all of a sudden these suited men walk into their house and are telling the guy they're not doing a good job...So, is this a really fucked up Halloween horror house just for fun? Or was there something more to it? I dunno, it's what bugged me about this film, aside from not being all that scary.
This movie does have a few moments, but it's more notable for who is in it, than the movie itself really.

The 4th film in the Texas Chainsaw Massacre franchise is the unnecessarily long-titled "TCM: The Next Generation (The Return of the Texas Chainsaw Massacre)" and, much like its title, it is stupid and unnecessary in its attempt to replicate Tobe Hooper's original film and transplant it to a more "modern" time...and by that I unfortunately mean the '90s.  It was quite clear to me while watching this that the filmmakers were trying to steal/borrow as many things as they possibly could from Hooper's film without making an official remake.  This resulted in nearly all of the original ideas from the first film being rehashed, including everything from the same kills being used again to the final shot of the film being replicated, where Leatherface is shown spinning his chainsaw around in rage (this time with far less purpose).  Let's just say, every single one of these things was better the first time around.  

There is also a surprising lack of blood from the kills (which are all extremely lame) demonstrating  an attempt at replicating the "implied violence" effect that was accomplished in the original.  However, while the kills in Hooper's film somehow still managed to shock us, the kills in this sequel simply feel like the shots of the victim dying were cut out in the editing process.  The effect feels disjointed and removes the viewer from the intensity of the moment.  One of the few things that I did genuinely enjoy is the fact that Leatherface dabbles in a bit of cross-dressing here, which I found to fit his character quite well and actually be equally hilarious and terrifying.  Also, Zellweger and McConaughey are both fun to watch, especially McConaughey who delivers a crazy over-the-top performance and sports an unexplained remote-controlled robotic attachment on his leg.  The fact that the two lead roles are both played by current A-listers who didn't know any better is probably reason enough to watch this mess of a film, provided you don't pay any money for it and you don't mind seeing some truly absurd and occasionally disturbing scenes.

If you've seen the last three films of the series, and you haven't seen this film, do not watch this, save your time and money. This film is terrible beyond words.
